newsitem.title: POLAND: Poland's shipyard group delayed until 1997.
newsitem.headline: Poland's shipyard group delayed until 1997.

text.p: The creation of a state-controlled holding group, comprising two Polish shipyards, an engine maker and possibly a steel mill, will be delayed until next year, PAP news agency reported on Monday.
PAP quoted deputy industry minister Tadeusz Soroka as saying that the government was likely to begin the creation of the group in the first guarter of 1997.
"Apart from firms from the shipbuilding industry we would like the group to embrace companies from other sectors," PAP quoted Soroka as saying.

Privatisation Minister Wieslaw Kaczmarek has earlier said the group -- including shipyards in the ports of Gdynia and Szczecin, the H. Cegielski engine maker from the western city of Poznan, the Huta Czestochowa steel mill and several banks -- would be set up by the end of 1996.
The ministry has said the scheme is designed to strengthen the shipbuilding industry against foreign competition.
Last year the industry recorded an aggregate loss of $7 million despite a flood of orders, with the notable exception of the Szczecin yard just breaking even on record $460 million sales.
